title: How close are we to making the Nikola Tesla free energy concept a reality? - Quora

response.answer_text: Tesla had two different ideas about “free energy.” One was about obtaining it and the other was about distributing it. The “obtaining” idea involved, roughly, somehow stringing antennas and wires up to the ionosphere to tap into the electrical potential difference between the Earth and “up there.” That idea is impractical because of the length and weight of the wires required, and the size and weight of the antennas. Cool in theory, unrealistic in practice. It’s not like this idea was kept secret or anything; if it was a sensible idea then there would be power companies doing this and making a profit on it. The “distributing” idea involved building big-ass coils to transmit power to whole cities the way wireless chargers do to your phone. You’d essentially be turning a city into a huge transformer or induction range, and everybody living in it would be walking around in a periodic magnetic field. Anybody could tap into the electricity just by setting up a coil. This idea isn’t completely impractical technically, though it would waste some energy heating up any bit of metal in the field. It’s impractical from a public health point of view because there are likely to be negative effects from living inside a strong fluctuating magnetic field, in a way that’s far more real than the one today’s 5G conspiracy nutters worry about. It’s impractical economically because who would want to build a lot of expensive infrastructure to provide a population with energy in a way that can’t be metered and charged for? Regular ol’ copper wire turns out to be more efficient and more practical in every way. And remember, this is just about distribution — the electrical energy would still have to come from somewhere. See above. In summary: Both of Tesla’s “free energy” ideas turned out to be garbage, and that’s why they aren’t implemented today. There are many clueless people whose IQ drops by several dozen when they hear the word “free,” and these people continue to worship the idea of someone who invented a mechanism for giving them something for nothing.
